title: NVIDIA CEO: WTF is going on with AI
transcript: Nvidia's CEO Jensen Wang just spoke at the World Economic Forum in Davos and he was on top form. I've pulled out my three favorite clips from his interview. The last one specifically is a banger. But firstly, a bonus intro which did make me laugh. It is my real pleasure to introduce Jensen Wong, who is somebody I admire, somebody I've watched, and somebody who has been a teacher to me on the journey of learning about technology and AI. It is amazing watching how he led Nvidia. And um I don't measure myself on on comparisons, but I like this one comparison. So since Dvidia has been public, which was in 1999, same year as Black Rockck, oh boy. Okay. No, Nvidia's total return for its shareholders has been a compounded 30 37%. Just think about that. What would that mean to every pension fund if they invested in Nvidia as an IPO? The the amount of successes we have with everybody's retirement. At the same time, uh Black Rockck's annual wise uh total return has been 21%. not so bad for a a financial services company but uh uh it certainly pales and uh and so that but that is just a really great indication of Jensen's leadership the positioning of Nvidia and also it is a great statement about what in the world believes in the future of Nvidia so Jensen congratulations on that journey and I know we have many more years of that journey ahead of us. Thank you. I appreciate that. My only regret was at the IPO, after the IPO, I wanted to buy my parents something nice and so I sold Nvidia stock at a valuation of $300 million. Uh, the company was at a valuation of $300 million and I bought them a Mercedes S-Class. It It is the most expensive car in the world. Okay, so in my third favorite clip, which we're about to watch right now, Jensen breaks down AI into five layers: energy, chips, cloud, models, and applications, and explains why we're only a few hundred billion into what's going to be a multi-trillion dollar buildout. Check it out. >> Now, the important thing about this is that because we're reinventing that entire computing stack, the question is, what is AI? You're asked when you think about AI, you think about the AI models, but it's really important to understand industrially AI is actually essentially a five layer cake. At the bottom is energy. AI because it's processed in real time and it generates intelligence in real time. It needs energy to do so. Energy is the first layer. The second layer is the layer that I live in. It's chips. Chips and computing infrastructure. The next layer above it is the cloud infrastructure, the cloud, the cloud services. The layer above that is the AI models. This is where most people think AI is. But don't forget that in order for those models to happen, you have to have all of the layers underneath it. But the most important layer and this is the layer that's happening right now. The reason why last year was an incredible year frankly for AI is that the AI models made so much progress that the layer above it which is ultimately the the layer that we all need to ex to succeed the application layer above that. And so this application layer could be in financial services, it could be in healthcare, it could be in manufacturing. This layer on top ultimately is where economic benefit will happen. But the important thing though because this computing platform requires all of the layers underneath it. It has started and you guys are everybody's seeing it right now. It has started the largest infrastructure buildout in human history. [clears throat] We're now a few hundred billion dollars into it. So we're a few hundred billion dollars into it. Uh Larry and I, we get the opportunity to work on many projects together. There are trillions of dollars of infrastructure that needs to be built out. And it's sensible. It's sensible because all of these contexts have to be processed so that the AI so that the models can generate the intelligence necessary to power the applications that ultimately sit on top. And so when you go back and when you reason about it layer by layer by layer and you you realize that the energy sector is now seeing extraordinary growth. The chip sector TSMC just announced they're going to manufact they're going to build 20 new chip plants. Foxcon working with us and Wistron and Quanta building 30 new computer plants which then go into these AI factories. So we have chip factories, computer factories and AI factories all being built around the world. >> And memory and memory, right? Exactly. Those chip fabs. Uh Micron has started investing $200 billion in the United States. SKH Highix is doing incredibly. Samsung is doing incredibly. You could see that entire chip layer growing incredibly today. And now of course we pay a lot of attention to the model layer but it's really exciting that the layer above them is really doing fantastically. And now one indicator is where are the VC funding going into last year 2025 was one of the largest years in VC funding ever and last year most of the funding went to what is called AI [clears throat] native companies. These are companies in healthcare, the company in robotics, incoming manufacturing, financial services, all of the large industries in the world. You're seeing huge investments going in to those AI natives because for the first time, the models are good enough to build on top of. >> AI is creating an entirely new industrial economy with five independent layers, and we're watching it get built in real time. Jensen's framing here is really useful because most people think of AI as chat bots or whatever model they're using, but that's like thinking the internet is just websites. The model is one layer. Underneath it, you've got energy, chips, cloud infrastructure, and above it, you've got the applications that actually touch people's lives. Each layer depends on the ones below it. You can't have great AI applications without great models. Can't have great models without cloud infrastructure. Can't have cloud infrastructure without chips. and can't have chips without, you guessed it, energy. It's a stack and every layer has to scale together. As Jensen says, TSMC is building 20 new chip plants. Foxcon, Wistron, and Quant are building 30 new computer factories. Micron's investing $200 billion in the US alone, and Jensen saying we're only a few hundred billion into what needs to be trillions. The investment so far, which already feels massive, is basically the down payment. The real buildout, according to Jensen, hasn't even started yet. And this explains why you're seeing so much activity across seemingly unrelated industries. Energy companies are suddenly relevant to AI. Memory manufacturers are seeing demand they never expected. Construction firms are building these massive data centers. We built out electricity grids. We built out telecom networks. We built out the internet. This is the next one, and it touches all of those. The thing that stood out to me is his point about the application layer finally taking off. 2025 saw record VC funding and most of it went to what Jensen calls AI native companies. Healthcare, robotics, manufacturing, financial services. These aren't AI research labs. They're companies using AI to solve real problems in traditional industries. That's the signal that we've crossed some threshold. The models got good, good enough that you can actually build businesses on top of them. And once that happens, the demand for everything underneath, the chips, the energy, the infrastructure just compounds. So that's the infrastructure picture. But the question everyone keeps asking is, what does that mean for jobs? Jensen addresses this head-on using radiology as a case study. 10 years ago, everyone said radiologists would be the first to go. AI could read scans better than humans. Here's what actually happened and why the framework he gives for thinking about any job is worth paying attention to. Quick plug before I play that clip. I built the AI course I wish I had and read before I started deep diving into AI. I break down everything from chips to foundation models to research labs to ontologies to some of the leading companies in physical AI and why it's such a big market. If you join today, you get lifetime access and the price will be increasing every time we add new modules, which we're thinking of doing soon. So, if you want to get in at the cheapest price, now is the best time to do that. Um the second thing to realize and and so we theorize about um the automation of of uh of tasks and things like that and what is the implication to jobs. Um you know I'll I'll just offer some anecdotes. These are real world anecdotes of what has actually happened. Remember 10 years ago I one of the first first professions that everybody thought was going to get wiped out was radiology. And the reason for that was the first AI that became superhuman in capability was computer vision. And the one of the largest applications of computer v vision is studying scans by radiologists. Well, 10 years later, it is true that AI has now completely permeated and diffused into every aspect of radiology. And [clears throat] it is true that radiologists um use uh AI to study scans. Now it the impact is 100% and the impact is completely real. However, not surprisingly I say not surprisingly if you reason from first principles not surprisingly the number of radiologists have gone up. Is that because a lack of trust of or is that because the human interaction with the with the results of AI is a better outcome? >> Exactly. The reason for that is because a radiologist their job the purpose of their job >> is to diagnose disease to help patients diagnose disease. That's the purpose of their job. The task of the job includes studying scans. The fact that they're able to study scans now infinitely fast allows them to spend more time with patients diagnosing their disease, interacting with the patients, interacting with other clinicians. Well, surprisingly, also not surprisingly, actually, as a result of that, the number of patients that the hospital can see has gone up because, you know, there a lot of people waiting a long time to get to get their scans done. And so now because the the number of patients have gone up, the revenues of the hospital has gone up, they hire more radiologists. This is the same thing is happening to nurses. We're 5 million nurses short in the United States um as a result of using AI to do the [clears throat] charting and the transcription of of uh the the uh the patient visits. uh nurses spend half of their time charting and now they could use AI technology in one particular company a bridge their a partner of ours doing incredible work as a result of that the nurses could spend more time visiting patients but touch that's right and because you can now see more patients and we're no longer bottle less bottlenecked by the number of nurses more patients could get into the hospital sooner as a result hospitals do better they hire more nurses And so surprisingly AI is increasing their not surprisingly AI is increasing their productivity. As a result the hospitals are doing better. They want to hire more people. You have too many people waiting too long to get into hospitals. And so these are two perfect examples. Now the easiest way to think about whether what is the impact of AI on a particular job is to understand whether the job what is the purpose of the job and what is the task of the job. My if you if you just put a camera on the two of us and just watched us, you would probably think the two of us are typists because I spend all of my time typing and and so if AI could automate so many so much word prediction and help us type then we would be out of jobs but obviously that's not our purpose and so the question is what is the purpose of your job in the case of radiologists and nurses is to care for people and that that purpose is enhance hands that made more productive because the task has been ma has automated and so to the extent that you can reason about each one of the people's purpose versus the task I think it's a helpful framework AI automates tasks not purposes and that distinction explains why radiologist jobs increased instead of disappearing radiology was supposed to be ground zero computer vision got superhuman at reading scans the technology completely penetrated the field and Jensen says it's been a 100% adoption and yet 10 Years later, there are more radiologists than ever before. Not fewer, more. The opposite of what everyone predicted. And it's worth understanding why. A radiologist's purpose is to diagnose disease and help patients. The task includes studying scans. AI made the task infinitely faster, which meant radiologists can now spend more time on the actual purpose, talking to patients, consulting with other doctors, making better diagnosises. The hospital can see more patients because they're no longer bottlenecked by scan reading time. Revenue goes up. They hire more radiologists. I think the key insight here is that most jobs exist because there's more demand than supply. There are always more patients who need care than there are people to care for them. There are always going to be more problems to solve than people solving them. When you make workers more productive, you start chipping away at that backlog of unmet demand. The 5 million nurse shortage in the US doesn't go away because AI discharting. It gets a little smaller because each nurse can now handle more patients. The practical takeaway is to think about your own work this way. If you watch yourself on camera all day, what would it look like you're doing? That's the framework. Purpose versus task. If AI automates a task, it probably makes the purpose more achievable, not less relevant. Now for the bonus clip. If you've enjoyed this video, please consider subscribing. >> So, [clears throat] what I'm hearing is we're far from an AI bubble. The question is, are we investing enough? Let's turn the turn it around because there are so many people talking about a bubble, but the question is what I'm hearing from you is, you know, are we investing enough to do what we need to do to broaden the global economy. And so, one good test on the AI bubble is to recognize that Nvidia has now has now millions of NVIDIA GPUs in the cloud. We're in every cloud. Um, you know, we're used everywhere. And if you try to rent an Nvidia GPU these days, it's so incredibly hard. And the spot price of GPU rentals is going up. Not just the latest generation, but two generation old GPUs. The spot price of rentals are going up. And the reason for that is because the number of AI companies that are being created, the number of companies shifting their R&D budget. Everybody ought to get engaged. Uh we need more energy. I think that we all recognize that. We need more land power in Shell. Um uh we need more uh trade skill workers. And in fact, that population of workforce is so strong here in Europe. >> Yes. >> In a lot of ways, the United States lost that um in the last, you know, 20, 30 years. Um but is still incredibly strong here in Europe. It's it's an extraordinary opportunity you got to take advantage of. And so I I would you know in I know that where where Larry and I work uh we uh we see the the investment opportunities um and the investment uh scale is going up. uh the number of startups as I mentioned earlier that LA 2025 the largest investment year in VC history over a hundred billion dollars around the world most of it was AI natives and so these AI companies are building basically the application layer above they're going to um you know and go build this future >> and I actually believe it's going to be a great investment for pension funds around the world to to be a part that to grow with this AI world. And this is one of my messages as so many political leaders. We need to make sure that the average pensioner, the average saver is is a part of that growth. If they're just watching it from the sidelines, you know, they're they're going to feel left out. And we want to invest in infrastructure, >> right? In infrastructure is a great investment option. title: Tom Lee Just Invested $200 Million Into...
transcript: I've got one heck of a video for you guys today. It contains Tom Lee, Mr. Beast, and Kathy Wood. In clip one, Tom Lee announces a $200 million investment partnering with Mr. Beast. And I'll explain why this could be a preview of how the entire creator economy gets restructured. Then in clip two, Kathy Wood makes a surprising admission about stable coins that I think reveals something bigger about where crypto is heading. Ethereum treasury company Bitmine is partnering uh with a YouTube powerhouse uh making a $200 million investment in Mr. Beast's uh company Beast Industries. Joining us exclusively ahead of uh today's Bitmind stockholder meeting, BitMine chairman Tom Lee. He's also head of research uh at Fundstrat, chief investment officer of Funstrat Capital and a CNBC contributor. U you got to explain this to everyone, including me. Um uh the rationale here, Tom. Uh good morning Joe. Um there's a lot of strategic rationale to this move made by Bitine. Um as you know Bitine is the largest Ethereum treasury company in the world. uh the largest holder of Ethereum and it's our view that Ethereum which is a smart contract platform is the future of finance where digitalization of not only dollars but stocks and equities is going to take place and over time that really blurs what is a service versus what's digital money um and that's where uh a collaboration and investment into beast industries makes sense um as you Mr. Beast is the number one content creator in the world. His content is watched more than for each of his videos 252 million views a month, which is more than the Super Bowl. And really, he is probably the iconic person for Gen Z, Gen Alpha, and arguably Millennials. So, he is probably one of the most important creators in the world. uh Beast Industries according to Jeff Henbold is planning to create a future platform of services which includes digital items and even financial services and that's really where a collaboration between beast industries and bit mine will make sense. So I think it's part of this sort of evolution of digital platforms and money and I think it's really uniting this, you know, the number one creator in the world with the biggest Ethereum platform in the world. >> Kind of getting it. Kind of getting it. Is there a reason um that you like the Ethereum blockchain more than than Salana or will will both exist? Could could you have done this with Salana? Uh I think there is going to be room for multiple blockchains. Uh Ethereum is the largest blockchain in the world. Uh it is almost uh 70% of all tokenized assets are taking place on Ethereum and Ethereum is extremely resilient. It's had a 100% uptime since inception. The only blockchain to smart contract platform to have never gone down. >> Right. There are but I guess there are differences and each uh each has its um you know people that that think that there are certain features about Salana that are better people that think that there are certain and it and it gets very arcane and uh and we get down in into a rabbit hole. So what would the future look like for the digital uh tokens that Mr. Beast that would be traveling across the Ethereum network? What are we talking about? Just describe it and how it would work. Um well it I think it's really going to be up to what beast industry unveils. So uh you know um I think it's if I was to imagine things that will happen. Uh number one we know that stable coins have become uh increasingly mainstream. You know it is really the breakout product of 2025. And we also know that Wall Street firms like Black Rockck and Robin Hood want to tokenize almost everything from stocks to credit to real estate and eventually things like intellectual property and even loyalty points. uh I imagine that those are the kind of products that could be emerging on any future uh services platform and that's where it's going to be a natural fit between a company like Bitmine and what Beast Industries does and but you know from Bitmine's perspective uh Beast Industries you know is a a very unique company I mean for us I think as just an investment and you know being part of the cap table where there are some really high quality venture capitalists and other investors uh represents a good investment opportunity for us or what we call a moonshot. The Mr. Beast deal signals that Gen Z creators are about to become on-ramps for institutional crypto adoption. So Tom Lee runs Fundstrat and he's been one of the more accurate crypto analysts over the past few years. He's got a call on Bitcoin hitting $150,000. He has some pretty bullish Ethereum targets, too. And to be fair to him, generally he's got a pretty good track record. And now he's putting $200 million into Mr. Be's company through Bitine, which is basically trying to do for Ethereum what Michael Sailor did for Bitcoin with strategy. Buy the asset, hold it on a corporate balance sheet, use the company as a vehicle to accumulate more. The interesting part is the thesis here. Tom's betting that Ethereum becomes the settlement layer for digital finance. Tokenized stocks, digital dollars, loyalty programs, all of it running on Ethereum rails. And who has the biggest distribution to the people who actually use this stuff? Content creators with massive audiences. Mr. Beast often gets 250 million views in a video. That's more than a Super Bowl. He's reaching Gen Z, Gen Alpha, the demographics that grew up with digital first everything. Now, I think what's actually happening here is a recognition that the path to mainstream crypto adoption runs through culture, not through institutions. Banks are slow, regulators are slow. If Mr. Beast launches a loyalty program on Ethereum or digital collectibles or whatever Beast Industries ends up building. That's potentially hundreds of millions of young people interacting with blockchain infrastructure without even knowing it. They're not going to care about the underlying technology. They just want the thing their favorite creator is offering. And this connects to something bigger. The Genius Act just passed the Senate with a 68 to30 vote. Banks can now custody crypto. Stable coins are getting proper regulation frameworks. All of this infrastructure is getting built, but it needs users. Traditional finance doesn't bring users, it brings capital. Creators bring users. So, when Tom Lee says he's uniting the number one Ethereum platform with the number one creator in the world, I think he's actually building a distribution channel for institutional crypto products disguised as a creator partnership. Quick plug. If you've been meaning to get a proper understanding of AI, I built a course that teaches everything from the first principles to some more advanced ideas. Basically, I built the course I wish I had when I first started researching AI. If you join now, you get lifetime access and the price goes up each time we add new modules, which we're thinking about doing soon. So, if you want in now is the lowest price. Now, we just had the optimistic case for how crypto reaches the mainstream. But Kathy Wood's take adds some nuance to this picture. In the next clip, Kathy makes an admission that surprised a lot of people that stable coins are kind of eating into Bitcoin's original use case. But then she explains why she thinks Bitcoin still has a much bigger role to play. Let's dive in. >> And boy, Andrew Ross Sorcin ran with it when when I said on CNBC uh Squawkbox one morning, "Well, you know, it seems to me that stable coins are usurping a role that we thought Bitcoin would play uh when we f put out our first white paper in 2015." and uh and and and and that does seem to be the case. Uh uh we do see a lot of activity especially in emerging markets um focused on stable coin. Stable coins are serving as the insurance policy that we thought Bitcoin would provide to people in emerging markets um uh as they were trying to protect themselves from you know confiscation of their wealth whether it's in the form of inflation or just outright confiscation and capital controls and so forth. He ran with that. But uh uh I had to put that in context. That was everything else equal while something else was going on. Uh and that was the gold price moving up as rapidly and as much as it has during the past year. Uh and so the digital gold role of Bitcoin um we think is that much more valuable and probably is more than offset what I just said about stable coin. So I think uh we're sorting through that and I think in terms of the future and next year you know we have seen very little institutional buyin it is just beginning uh and uh I think if we get the US for example not uh adding just confiscated Bitcoin to uh a strategic reserve but you know out there buying and we don't know if that's going to be the case. But if they if they were to do so, I have a feeling that would set off what we're all waiting for, which is, you know, the scarcity value to reassert itself again now that we're near 20 million Bitcoin outstanding and we only have one more million to go. Uh I think the party has just begun uh in that way and so we're still very optimistic. >> I think it's been the best year honestly. like forget about forget about price, right? Like if you look at last year like it went from 50k to 100k like for Christmas and after Trump, but I think this year even is if price is down or flat, like the fundamental I think setup for Bitcoin and crypto in general, like what we've had this year is the best year by far. I think like 2025 is going to be like one era before that and one era like after that. I think um like regulation the the genius act the work that's been done like on the the clarity act and I think the net new entrant into Bitcoin and digital assets I think it's the best setup basically that we've seen in terms of fundamentals like for the the next years right I think you see that like the the players that are entering the space right and that's why I mean maybe we'll talk about the four year cycle but what I feel confident is their companies and people like bu have a long-term vision, right? They're building stuff on top of Bitcoin or using crypto. They're not here for 6 months or a year, right? And so I think like volatility is going to go down. And also just the use cases like you've seen like CFTC with the the pilot that they want to introduce Bitcoin and Ether as collateral like in derivatives market like that is huge like unlocking new use cases for Bitcoin for like institutional adoption. And so I just like I'm seeing, you know, like looking at the last A16Z crypto report, they say there's roughly between like 40 and 50 million monthly active users in crypto in general. Uh I think it's pretty clear the net new entrant both like user and kind of capital is is very different, right? And is more like long-term. Even like all the DATs you see, you know, I was seeing like Jack Mers with 21 Capital, like they're building stuff for the long term, right? With with with Bitcoin as a as a foundation. So, forget about price, but I think fundamentals and where the space is, it's been the best year I think in in a long long time in in my opinion. So, I think 26 looks super bright. Stable coins have captured the payments use case that Bitcoin was supposed to own, but that actually freed Bitcoin to become something more valuable, digital gold for institutions. So Cathy's making a really honest assessment here back in 2015 when ARC put out their first Bitcoin white paper. The thesis was that Bitcoin would be how people in emerging markets protected their wealth from inflation, currency devaluation, and capital controls. And she's admitting that stable coins, digital dollars, are actually doing that job instead. If you're in Argentina or Turkey and you want to protect your savings, you're probably using USDC, not Bitcoin. Stable coins give you dollar stability without the volatility. But here's another layer to the cake. She's saying that's fine because Bitcoin has a different role now. Gold went up 25% or so last year, and that's central banks buying it as a hedge against the dollar risk. Bitcoin is competing in that same category, not as a payment method, but as a store of value that sits outside the traditional financial system. And the math on scarcity is simple. 20 million Bitcoin already mined, only 1 million left to go. When the US government is potentially going to start buying instead of just holding confiscated coins, that's a supply squeeze on a level we haven't seen. And also, the other panelists made an interesting point that I think is underrated. He's saying, "Forget about price for a second. Just look at the infrastructure being built. The Genius Act gives stable coins a real regulatory framework. The Clarity Act is working its way through Congress to define what a security, what's a commodity, what's a payment token.
